main_definition: Connects at least two alternative words, phrases, clauses, sentences, etc. each of which could make a passage true. In English, this is the "inclusive or." The "exclusive or" is formed by "either [...] or".

meanings_and_examples.definition: Connects at least two alternative words, phrases, clauses, sentences, etc. each of which could make a passage true. In English, this is the "inclusive or." The "exclusive or" is formed by "either [...] or".
meanings_and_examples.example: He might get cancer, or be hit by a bus, or God knows what.

meanings_and_examples.definition: An operator denoting the disjunction of two propositions or truth values. There are two forms, the inclusive or and the exclusive or.

example.inclusive_or: You can have cake or ice cream for dessert today.
example.exclusive_or: The safe exit will lead to freedom or to a dead end, but not both.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Counts the elements before and after as two possibilities.
meanings_and_examples.example: You can either take the red pill or the blue pill to experience different realities.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Otherwise (a consequence of the condition that the previous is false).
meanings_and_examples.example: It's raining! Come inside or you'll catch a cold!
